comments.body: Why not just have `fromSet` be the default constructor? Set literals are are pretty concise, don't have a limit of four  items. Is it that they won't assert if there are duplicates?

Because it's just more concise and easy to read when you define them.  Compare this:
```dart
LogicalKeySet(LogicalKeyboardKey.tab): const Intent(NextFocusAction.key),
LogicalKeySet(LogicalKeyboardKey.shift, LogicalKeyboardKey.tab): const Intent(PreviousFocusAction.key),
```
with this:
```dart
LogicalKeySet(<LogicalKeyboardKey>{LogicalKeyboardKey.tab}): const Intent(NextFocusAction.key),
LogicalKeySet(<LogicalKeyboardKey>{LogicalKeyboardKey.shift, LogicalKeyboardKey.tab}): const Intent(PreviousFocusAction.key}),
```

And it's not because of the duplicate checking, because Dart sets aren't multisets, so there are no duplicates in a `Set` anyhow.

The vast majority of key bindings will be single keys (or maybe two), so I thought it made sense to streamline those a bit.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +34,38 @@  /// The `key1` parameter must not be null. The same [KeyboardKey] may
  /// not be appear more than once in the set.
  KeySet(
    T key1, [
    T key2,

comments.body: Do you mean this should crash in debug mode but pass in release mode? I kind of get the intention, but still why would anyone release a piece of code that crashes in debug mode?

The reason is that unless they press the key that causes the problem during their testing, they won't know that it crashes in debug mode.

And I don't think an invalid key sequence should crash the app in release mode: it can be ignored if it gets that far.
Maybe you can add this to the comment. Your explanation is pretty helpful.
OK, sounds good, added a comment.
I think this can be `late`, and then the getter below can return a non-nullable value.

OK, I see. Can we mark the `manager` getter as non-nullable and return `widget.manager ?? _internalManager!` from it?  The `manager` getter shouldn't ever return null when accessed, since one or the other of `_internalManager` and `widget.manager` should always be non-null.
We should assert that that's actually true here so we notice when that actually ever changes.
Don't we already have to do this matching to dispatch the actual key-press? Can we re-use that logic here?
Never mind, just scrolled down and saw that the re-use is the other way around. That works :)
